Award.AwardTitle: Encouraging Interdisciplinary Learning in Science, Math, and Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Encouraging Interdisciplinary Learning in Science, Math, and Computing" project at the College of Saint Scholastica will advance STEM knowledge and understanding by piloting strategies to engage and support students at a private liberal arts college, with an emphasis on recruiting female, first-generation, and other underrepresented groups. Scholarships and targeted activities will help a cohort of academically talented students with demonstrated financial need achieve aspirations for STEM careers or graduate school, while also boosting the STEM workforce. The project's interdisciplinary focus will familiarize students with the dynamic nature of research and employment in STEM disciplines.

Project objectives include: 1) Increasing the recruitment of talented, financially needy students in STEM majors, with special encouragement to groups underrepresented in STEM; 2) Encouraging S-STEM Scholars to pursue undergraduate research experiences or internships; 3) Achieve 90% degree attainment in STEM fields among participants, through forming a strong peer group engaged in STEM mentoring, career preparation, and academic support activities; 4) Achieve 80% placement in STEM graduate programs or careers, with a focus on meeting regional and national workforce needs. The project will employ a broad base of research-proven methods to engage female and other underrepresented students, including: intrusive advising, pedagogy to reduce stereotype threat, promoting a growth mindset and active learning, peer mentoring, workshops, field trips, internships, and research experiences. Lessons learned and effective practices that emerge from the program evaluation data will be disseminated to the education community and help enlarge the knowledge base regarding attributes and practices of successful scholarship programs of this type.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past five years, the NSF S-STEM scholarship program at The College of St.Scholastica (CSS) has worked to increase the number of students graduating in STEM fields and to better prepare these graduates for STEM careers or graduate school. The program focused on students who are talented but financially disadvantaged, with an emphasis on women, first-generation college students, and students underrepresented in STEM fields. Overall, the program supported 57 students majoring in biochemistry, chemistry, biology, mathematics, and computer sciences. Of the 57, 34 scholars (59.6%) were women, and 8 scholars (14.0%) were students of color.  Nearly half of the scholars were first-generation college students.  Over the five-year grant period, our scholars achieved an average cumulative GPA of 3.65.  

Each student received a scholarship award of up to $6,500 per year and had the opportunity to participate in activities that provided support and exposed scholars to many STEM research and career opportunities available.  Our S-STEM program had programmatic elements such as: one-on-one faculty mentoring, field trips to local and regional STEM labs in academia and industry, support for GRE prep courses and registration, funding to attend STEM conferences, and cohort activities to build community and promote peer support. One example of a cohort activity was a novel approach to disseminate information on how to find and apply for summer research and internship opportunities. Advanced students who had participated in summer research or internships were able to quickly pass on their experience and information to more novice students in a ?speed dating? informational session. The S-STEM team presented this approach at the Experimental Biology 2018 meeting. Overall, this programming, particularly faculty mentoring, likely contributed significantly to the 94.8% graduation rate in STEM for S-STEM Scholars compared to a 65.4% graduation rate for all CSS STEM majors during the same time period.

A significant highlight of our program was that a large number of students participated in research experiences and/or internships.  Overall, 30 scholars (52.6%) participated in research - examples include: serving as a biology research assistant for the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and summer undergraduate research experience at diverse settings such as Sam Houston State University, Emory University, Mayo Clinic, Stanford University, and Vanderbilt University. These experiences gave students the opportunity to gain experience for graduate school applications.  Additionally, students were able to share their research findings and network with other STEM professionals at national conferences (including National Conference of Undergraduate Research [NCUR], National American Chemical Society [ACS] Meeting, Grace Hopper Convention,  Experimental Biology and National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers [NOBCChE].  In addition to research experiences, 33 scholars (57.9%) participated in internships - examples include: Information Management Intern at Essentia Health, Development Intern at C.H. Robinson, Software Development intern at the National Atmospheric Release Advisory Center (Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory), Cellulose Technician at Sappi and Analytics intern for Duluth Huskies baseball team.  These activities and experiences have contributed to strong STEM academic and career aspirations among a number of our program participants. Graduates have pursued further education in STEM, including pursuing a Chemistry Ph.D. at the University of Michigan, Biomedical Sciences Ph.D. at St. Louis University, and Biomedical Sciences Ph.D. at the Mayo Clinic and Biochemistry Ph.D. at the University of Minnesota.  Graduates have also entered into a variety of STEM careers such as  IT/programming positions at Allianz, Securian, Bank of America, and Keyot; a consulting and a wildlife biology position with the United States Geological Survey; Application Developer for Securian Financial; a software engineer at CH Robinson; Clinical Laboratory Technologist for the Department of Laboratory Medicine and Pathology and at the Mayo Clinic and an Educational Technologist and Instructional Designer for The College of St. Scholastica. Follow-up contacts have confirmed that 90.7% (39 of 43) of our S-STEM alumni have continued on to STEM graduate education and/or STEM careers.  These are significant results for CSS, a regional college with no STEM graduate programs, where 35% of students have family incomes below $50,000 and 70% are from rural/small communities with few STEM role models.

The S-STEM scholarship program at The College of St. Scholastica has had a significant impact in supporting students on their journeys toward STEM graduate studies and careers.  As one scholar noted,  ?I consider the S-STEM program one of the most important parts of my education. I wouldn?t have chosen this specific path for my future without the impact S-STEM had on me.?   We greatly appreciate the support of the National Science Foundation, and we look forward to continuing this work in the future.


 

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2020
Modified by: Melanie Talaga
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Over the past five years, the NSF S-STEM scholarship program at The College of St.Scholastica (CSS) has worked to increase the number of students graduating in STEM fields and to better prepare these graduates for STEM careers or graduate school. The program focused on students who are talented but financially disadvantaged, with an emphasis on women, first-generation college students, and students underrepresented in STEM fields. Overall, the program supported 57 students majoring in biochemistry, chemistry, biology, mathematics, and computer sciences. Of the 57, 34 scholars (59.6%) were women, and 8 scholars (14.0%) were students of color. Nearly half of the scholars were first-generation college students. Over the five-year grant period, our scholars achieved an average cumulative GPA of 3.65. Each student received a scholarship award of up to $6,500 per year and had the opportunity to participate in activities that provided support and exposed scholars to many STEM research and career opportunities available. Our S-STEM program had programmatic elements such as: one-on-one faculty mentoring, field trips to local and regional STEM labs in academia and industry, support for GRE prep courses and registration, funding to attend STEM conferences, and cohort activities to build community and promote peer support. One example of a cohort activity was a novel approach to disseminate information on how to find and apply for summer research and internship opportunities. Advanced students who had participated in summer research or internships were able to quickly pass on their experience and information to more novice students in a ?speed dating? informational session. The S-STEM team presented this approach at the Experimental Biology 2018 meeting. Overall, this programming, particularly faculty mentoring, likely contributed significantly to the 94.8% graduation rate in STEM for S-STEM Scholars compared to a 65.4% graduation rate for all CSS STEM majors during the same time period. A significant highlight of our program was that a large number of students participated in research experiences and/or internships. Overall, 30 scholars (52.6%) participated in research - examples include: serving as a biology research assistant for the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and summer undergraduate research experience at diverse settings such as Sam Houston State University, Emory University, Mayo Clinic, Stanford University, and Vanderbilt University. These experiences gave students the opportunity to gain experience for graduate school applications. Additionally, students were able to share their research findings and network with other STEM professionals at national conferences (including National Conference of Undergraduate Research [NCUR], National American Chemical Society [ACS] Meeting, Grace Hopper Convention, Experimental Biology and National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers [NOBCChE]. In addition to research experiences, 33 scholars (57.9%) participated in internships - examples include: Information Management Intern at Essentia Health, Development Intern at C.H. Robinson, Software Development intern at the National Atmospheric Release Advisory Center (Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory), Cellulose Technician at Sappi and Analytics intern for Duluth Huskies baseball team. These activities and experiences have contributed to strong STEM academic and career aspirations among a number of our program participants. Graduates have pursued further education in STEM, including pursuing a Chemistry Ph.D. at the University of Michigan, Biomedical Sciences Ph.D. at St. Louis University, and Biomedical Sciences Ph.D. at the Mayo Clinic and Biochemistry Ph.D. at the University of Minnesota. Graduates have also entered into a variety of STEM careers such as IT/programming positions at Allianz, Securian, Bank of America, and Keyot; a consulting and a wildlife biology position with the United States Geological Survey; Application Developer for Securian Financial; a software engineer at CH Robinson; Clinical Laboratory Technologist for the Department of Laboratory Medicine and Pathology and at the Mayo Clinic and an Educational Technologist and Instructional Designer for The College of St. Scholastica. Follow-up contacts have confirmed that 90.7% (39 of 43) of our S-STEM alumni have continued on to STEM graduate education and/or STEM careers. These are significant results for CSS, a regional college with no STEM graduate programs, where 35% of students have family incomes below $50,000 and 70% are from rural/small communities with few STEM role models. The S-STEM scholarship program at The College of St. Scholastica has had a significant impact in supporting students on their journeys toward STEM graduate studies and careers. As one scholar noted, ?I consider the S-STEM program one of the most important parts of my education. I wouldn?t have chosen this specific path for my future without the impact S-STEM had on me.? We greatly appreciate the support of the National Science Foundation, and we look forward to continuing this work in the future. Last Modified: 08/31/2020 Submitted by: Melanie Talaga
